text: Herb-Drug Interaction between Echinacea purpurea and Etravirine in HIV-Infected Patients José Moltó,corresponding authora,b Marta Valle,b,c Cristina Miranda,a Samandhy Cedeño,d Eugenia Negredo,a and Bonaventura Cloteta,b,d Author information Article notes Copyright and License information PMC Disclaimer Go to: Abstract  The aim of this open-label, fixed-sequence study was to investigate the potential of the botanical supplement Echinacea purpurea to interact with etravirine, a nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor of HIV.

text: Echinacea was well tolerated, and all participants completed the study.

text: The GMR for etravirine coadministered with E. purpurea relative to etravirine alone was 1.07 (90% CI, 0.81 to 1.42) for the maximum concentration, 1.04 (90% CI, 0.79 to 1.38) for the area under the concentration-time curve from 0 to 24 h, and 1.04 (90% CI, 0.74 to 1.44) for the concentration at the end of the dosing interval.

text: In conclusion, the coadministration of E. purpurea with etravirine was safe and well tolerated in HIV-infected patients; our data suggest that no dose adjustment for etravirine is necessary.

text: Go to: INTRODUCTION  More than half of HIV-infected patients express interest in taking some kind of complementary therapy in addition to their antiretroviral regimens at some point during the course of treatment (15, 16, 19).
label: Pathology
Drug

text: These patients usually choose dietary and herbal supplements and take them without medical supervision.
label: Herb name

text: Nonetheless, such botanical supplements may influence the activity of various enzymes and transporters involved in the absorption, distribution, and metabolism of antiretroviral drugs, putting patients at risk of potential herb-drug interactions (11, 14).
label: Parameter
Drug

text: Echinacea preparations rank among the herbal remedies most commonly taken by HIV-infected patients (2, 3, 13), probably because of their hypothesized immunostimulant properties (20, 21).
label: Herb name
Herb name
Pathology
Pathology

text: Constituents of Echinacea purpurea have the potential to interact with cytochrome P450, providing a reason to suspect herb-drug interactions involving CYP3A4 substrates, including many antiretroviral agents (1, 10, 18).
label: Herb name
Parameter
Parameter
Drug

text: However, we observed no significant interaction between E. purpurea and the HIV-protease inhibitor darunavir in a previous study with HIV-infected patients (17), a finding we attributed to the fact that our patients were also receiving ritonavir.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Target
Drug
Pathology
Drug

text: Ritonavir causes nearly complete inhibition of CYP3A4 activity, possibly offsetting the potential influence of E. purpurea on CYP3A4 activity in that study.
label: Drug
Target
Parameter
Herb name
Parameter

text: Etravirine is a nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor of HIV which is primarily metabolized by the hepatic CYP3A4 and, to a lesser extent, by the CYP2C family, followed by glucuronidation (12).
label: Drug
Parameter
Parameter

text: Induction of CYP3A4 activity by E. purpurea could therefore theoretically result in inadequately low etravirine concentrations.
label: Target
Parameter
Herb name
Drug
Parameter

text: The magnitude of this potential interaction could be ameliorated by using etravirine in combination with a ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitor (12).
label: Drug
Drug

text: However, there is a growing interest in using etravirine once daily without a protease inhibitor (8; P. Echeverría, A. Bonjoch, J. Puig, R. Paredes, G. Sirera, J. R. Santos, J. Moltó, B. Clotet, and E. Negredo, presented at the 51st Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, 2011), a scenario where possible CYP3A4 induction might be more relevant.
label: Drug
Frequency
Drug
Parameter

text: The objective of the present study was therefore to evaluate the potential of E. purpurea to interact with etravirine in the absence of ritonavir.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: Go to: MATERIALS AND METHODS  Study design.

This open-label, fixed-sequence study enrolled 15 HIV-infected patients who had been receiving antiretroviral therapy with etravirine (400 mg once daily) for at least 4 weeks and whose HIV-1 RNA load in plasma was <50 copies/ml.
label: Study
Cohort
Pathology
Drug
Drug
Amount
Frequency
Duration
Pathology
Parameter
Amount

text: Patients on concomitant treatment with ritonavir or other CYP3A4 inhibitors or with a history of suboptimal treatment adherence were excluded.
label: Drug
Target

text: All patients gave written informed consent before enrollment, the protocol was approved by our hospital's ethics committee and the Spanish Medicines and Medical Devices Agency, and the study was performed according to the stipulations of the Declaration of Helsinki and registered (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier, NCT01347658).
label: Study

text: Patients took capsules containing E. purpurea root extract (Arkocápsulas Echinácea, lot no.
label: Herb name
Herb part
Extraction process

text: W064636A; Arkopharma) at a dosage of 500 mg every 8 h from days 1 to 14.
label: Amount
Frequency
Duration

text: All pills came from a single lot, which was externally controlled and certified to contain 100% of the labeled content of E. purpurea.
label: Herb name

text: Antiretroviral treatment remained unchanged.
label: Drug

text: Serial blood samples to determine etravirine concentrations in plasma were collected immediately before and 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 24 h after a witnessed morning dose of etravirine on day 0 and at the same times before and after etravirine plus E. purpurea on day 14.
label: Drug
Parameter
Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: On both days, etravirine was taken with a standard 550-kcal breakfast whose composition was 43% carbohydrate, 39% fat, and 18% protein.
label: Herb name
Amount
Parameter
Amount
Parameter
Amount
Parameter

text: Demographic and clinical variables (age, body weight and height, and use of concomitant drugs, including over-the-counter medications) were recorded.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Parameter

text: Safety was evaluated by clinical interview and physical examination, as well as by the laboratory assessments (blood counts, chemistry, CD4+ T-cell count, and HIV-1 RNA load), on days 0, 14, and 28.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Pathology
Parameter

text: To enhance adherence to scheduled clinical visits and the treatment protocol, patients were provided with a visit calendar.
Apart from days 0 and 14, drug intake was not directly observed; adherence was assessed by means of a diary, in which the patient recorded medication intake, and by pill count on day 14.
Analytical and pharmacokinetic analysis.
Blood samples for etravirine determinations were collected into K-ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid–containing 10-ml tubes.
label: Drug
Extraction process
Amount

text: Plasma was isolated by centrifugation (3,200 × g for 15 min) and stored at −20°C until analysis.
label: Duration
Amount
Parameter

text: Etravirine concentrations were determined by high-performance liquid chromatography with a fluorescence detector (Multifluorescence detector 2475; Waters) according to a validated method.
label: Drug
Parameter

text: Chromatographic separation was performed on a Sunfire C18 column (particle size 5 μm, 4.6 by 150 mm; Waters) protected by a SecurityGuard C18 column (4.0 by 3.0 mm; Phenomenex).
The fluorescence detector was set at 299 and 396 nm for excitation and emission wavelengths, respectively.
label: Amount
Amount
Parameter

text: The drug was extracted from plasma by liquid-liquid extraction with tert-butyl methyl ether.
label: Extraction process

text: The mobile phase consisted of a gradient elution with phosphate buffer (50 mM) in acetonitrile (pH 6.70).
label: Extraction process
Amount
Parameter
Amount

text: The method was linear over the range of 0.01 to 2.40 mg/liter.
The intraday and interday coefficients of variation were less than 10%.

Our laboratory subscribes to the external quality assurance program organized by the Association for Quality Assessment in Therapeutic Drug Monitoring and Clinical Toxicology of Radboud University Nijmegen Medical Centre, Nijmegen, the Netherlands (6).
Etravirine pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated for each individual using a noncompartmental approach by means of WinNonlin software application (version 2.0; Pharsight, Mountain View, CA).
label: Drug
Parameter

text: The area under the concentration-time curve during the dose interval (AUC0–24) was calculated by means of the linear trapezoidal rule.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: Maximum concentrations (Cmax), and the concentrations at the end of the dosing interval (C24), were obtained by inspection of the concentration data.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Parameter

text: Statistical analysis.
Data analysis was carried out using SPSS version 15.0 statistical software.
Etravirine pharmacokinetic parameters were described by the geometric mean and compared between days 0 and 14 by the geometric mean ratio (GMR).
label: Drug
Parameter
Parameter

text: Pharmacokinetic parameters were natural log-transformed before analysis, and confidence intervals (CIs) for means (and for the difference between two means) were constructed on the natural log scale based on an analysis of variance (ANOVA) model with treatment as a fixed effect.
label: Parameter

text: The results were then exponentiated and reported with 90% CIs.
A power calculation indicated that 15 patients would provide an 80% chance of detecting a 25% difference in the AUC0–24 for etravirine at a level of significance of 0.05 (P value).
label: Parameter
Drug

text: Go to: RESULTS  A total of 15 Caucasian HIV-infected patients were enrolled.
label: Cohort
Ethnic group
Pathology

text: Overall, 10 (66.7%) were males, and 4 (26.7%) were coinfected with hepatitis C virus (HCV).
label: Sex
Pathology

text: The median age was 46 years (interquartile range, 41 to 50), and the median body weight was 76 kg (interquartile range, 68 to 92).
label: Age

text: Other antiretroviral drugs being taken in addition to etravirine included tenofovir-emtricitabine (10 patients) and abacavir-lamivudine (5 patients).
label: Drug

Drug

text: The median CD4+ T cell count was 799 cells/mm3 (range, 541 to 946).
label: Parameter
Amount
Amount

text: The echinacea preparation was well tolerated, and all participants completed the study.
label: Herb name

text: Patients were fully adherent to antiretroviral and echinacea treatments, none reported drug-related adverse events during the study, and all had an HIV-1 RNA load of <50 copies/ml at the end of the study.
label: Drug

text: Etravirine pharmacokinetics.

text: One participant displayed etravirine concentrations which were near 10 times higher than those observed in the rest of the patients in both study periods.
label: Drug

text: This patient was considered to be a poor metabolizer/outlier, and he was excluded from the pharmacokinetic analysis.
The mean plasma concentration-time curves of etravirine in the presence and absence of E. purpurea are shown in Fig.

text: 1, and comparisons of etravirine pharmacokinetic parameters between days 0 and 14 are summarized in Table 1.
label: Drug

text: Etravirine concentration curves were superimposed, and no significant treatment effects were observed for any of the primary pharmacokinetic parameters after administration of etravirine with (day 14) or without (day 0) E. purpurea.

Go to: DISCUSSION  Our findings show that E. purpurea does not significantly affect the pharmacokinetics of etravirine in HIV-infected patients and therefore is not likely to put the patients at a significant herb-drug interaction risk.
label: Herb name
Drug
Pathology

text: The concern that E. purpurea might induce CYP3A4 activity in patients on antiretroviral agents, which are metabolized by this enzyme, is based on previous studies that found that midazolam exposure decreased by nearly 25% in the presence of an echinacea preparation (10, 18).
label: Herb name
Parameter
Drug
Drug
Herb name

text: However, two recent studies in individuals taking echinacea with boosted protease inhibitors found no significant interaction (17, 18).
label: Herb name
Drug

text: One study was performed in healthy volunteers who received lopinavir-ritonavir (18), and the other was conducted in HIV-infected patients taking darunavir-ritonavir (17).
label: Pathology
Drug
Pathology
Drug

text: In these studies, the lack of interaction could have been due to the coadministration of both lopinavir and darunavir with low doses of ritonavir, a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor which could have offset the CYP3A4-inducing effects of echinacea.
label: Drug
Drug
Drug
Parameter
Parameter
Herb name

text: Our findings in the present study contribute to attenuating any concerns that remain, however, given that the effect of echinacea on etravirine pharmacokinetics in our patients was negligible despite the lack of a boosted protease inhibitor.
label: Herb name
Drug
Parameter
Drug

text: Nonetheless, it is noteworthy that the magnitude of this interaction was quite variable at the individual level, from near 25% decreases to up to 50% increases in drug concentrations, possibly supporting monitoring etravirine concentrations in plasma if possible.
label: Amount
Amount
Parameter
Drug
Parameter

text: Three factors are relevant to interpreting our results.
First, in addition to CYP3A4 induction at the liver by E. purpurea, inhibition at the intestinal lumen has also been reported (10) and could also offset the potential induction of hepatic CYP3A4.
label: Target
Herb name
Target

text: Second, etravirine is a CYP3A4 inducer itself, and it could have masked potential induction of CYP3A by echinacea.
label: Drug
Target
Target
Herb name

text: Third, discrepancies between the labeled and the actual content of active constituents have been reported for many botanical preparations, to the extent that commercial products have not contained the labeled herb at all in some cases (7, 9).
label: Herb name

text: To avoid an effect of this potential limitation within our study, we purchased a single lot of E. purpurea from Arkopharma, which is a leader in the botanical supplement market in Europe.
label: Herb name

text: This company is externally controlled and has been granted the Good Manufacturing Practices certificate by the AFSSAPS (a French health products safety agency).
label: Ethnic group

text: Although etravirine is licensed for twice-daily dosing and for use in combination with a boosted protease inhibitor (12), the patients in this study were receiving 400 mg of etravirine once daily without a boosted protease inhibitor.
label: Drug
Frequency
Drug
Amount
Drug
Frequency
Drug

text: Interest in this off-label etravirine dosing regimen has emerged in the clinical setting (8; P. Echeverría, A. Bonjoch, J. Puig, R. Paredes, G. Sirera, J. R. Santos, J. Moltó, B. Clotet, and E. Negredo, presented at the 51st Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, 2011).
label: Drug

text: Even though etravirine exposure is known to be lower after once-daily administration (4), it is noteworthy that all our patients showed etravirine concentrations far above the protein-binding-adjusted EC50 for wild-type HIV (5) and all had undetectable viral loads at the end of the study (although this concentration cutoff value has not been clinically validated to be used in therapeutic drug-monitoring programs).
label: Drug
Frequency
Drug
Parameter
Parameter
Pathology
Parameter
Parameter

text: We conclude that the coadministration of E. purpurea with etravirine is safe and well tolerated in HIV-infected patients.
label: Herb name
Drug
Pathology

text: Our data suggest that no dose adjustment for etravirine is necessary in this scenario.
label: Drug
